EVIDENCE: A controlled-feeding trial conducted in China on 217 healthy volunteers highlighted that a high-fat diet modifies the gut microbiota composition, increasingBacteroidesandAlistipes, more abundant in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), and reducingFaecalibacterium, a butyrate-producing microorganism. Conversely, in the low-fat diet group, an increased abundance ofFaecalibacteriumandBlautiawas found, which favorably affect lipid metabolism

EVIDENCE: This high α-diversity dietary pattern (HiαDP) was characterized by greater intakes of fermented legumes, potatoes, vegetables, seaweeds, nuts/seeds, and tea and lower intakes of non-alcoholic beverages (e.g., carbonated and sweet beverages). The HiαDP was inversely correlated with Bacteroidetes (r = −0.17, p < 0.001), but positively correlated with the F/B ratio (r = 0.24, p < 0.001). At the genus level, the HiαDP was inversely correlated with Coenonia (r = −0.27), Prevotella (r = −0.22), and Tannerella (r = −0.22) within the Bacteroidetes phylum, but positively correlated with Lactobacillus (r = 0.23), Ruminococcus (r = 0.21), and Eubacterium (r = 0.20) and other 41 genera within the Firmicutes phylum.
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between high α-diversity dietary pattern (HiαDP) and Bacteroidetes(Bacteroidia)?

EVIDENCE: Several animal studies [68,69] have described a decrease in Bacteroidetes and an increase in Firmicutes and Proteobacteria in mice fed a high-fat diet (HFD), particularly SFA. Interestingly, these changes may gradually be restored through a control diet [68,69]. Another study [70] also showed a decrease in bifidobacteria in mice fed with HFD. Therefore, excessive intake of dietary fat, especially SFA, may lead to dysbiosis of the gut microbiota.

EVIDENCE: In fact, Suez et al. [98] demonstrated that calorie free artificial sweeteners (NASs) alter microbial metabolic pathways and link these changes to host susceptibility to metabolic diseases. In this study, a portion of healthy volunteers who typically did not take NAS and were given a dose of 5mg/kg of saccharin for one week had poor glucose tolerance. Analysis of the feces of "NAS" responders showed an increase in Bacteroides and Lactobacillus genera, while a decrease in Clostridium genus.

EVIDENCE: Most of the attention on the impact of cranberries on gut microbiota has been focused on the study of the effects of cranberry extract or juice on urinary tract pathogens and urinary tract infections (UTI) (2,3). However, this focus has expanded to encompass the broader antibacterial, antifungal, and antiviral effects of cranberries against Helicobacter pylori (4-6), Streptococcus mutans (7), Porphyromonas gingivalis (8), Staphylococcus aureus (9), Pseudomonas aeruginosa (10), Cryptococcus neoformans (6), and Haemophilus influenzae (11), Candida albicans (12,13), and enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (ExPEC) (14).
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between Cranberry and Helicobacter pylori?

EVIDENCE: A very recent study investigated healthy Italians following a modern PD for more than one year. The dominating phyla of the gut microbiome were Firmicutes (65.1 ± 2.1%) and Bacteroidetes (24.6 ± 2.2%), followed by Proteobacteria (4.4 ± 1.6%), Actinobacteria (3.4 ± 0.8%), and Verrucomicrobia (1.2 ± 0.5%). At the family level, the dominant bacteria were Ruminococcaceae, Lachnospiraceae, Bacteroidaceae, and Prevotellaceae, while, at the genus level, Bacteroides, Pervotella, and Faecalibacterium dominated [70]. Compared to Italians adhering to the MD, the PD microbiome diversity was much higher and comparable to that of the Hadza hunter–gatherers.
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between Paleolithic Diet and Firmicutes(Bacillota)?

EVIDENCE: In comparison to the control group (CON group), the ETEC group exhibited a decrease in the Simpson index and Shannon index in the colon of mice (P < 0.05) as depicted in Fig. 6. Nevertheless, in contrast to the ETEC group, the Observed_species in the colon of mice was found to be significantly higher in the BA.L group and BA.M group (P < 0.05). Additionally, an elevation in the Simpson index was observed in the colon of mice belonging to the BA.H group when compared to the ETEC group (P < 0.05). There was an observed pattern of statistical disparities in the β-diversity of colon microbiota between the ETEC group and the CON group, as well as between the BA.H and ETEC group (P < 0.10) (Fig. 7). According to Fig. 8, Firmicutes, Proteobacteria, and Bacteroidota exhibit dominance as bacterial phyla within the colon microbiota of mice. Furthermore, at the genus level, the predominant bacteria include Faecabacterium, Pseudomonas, and Lactobacillus. The LEfSe analysis demonstrated significant disparities in bacterial communities across the various treatment groups. Notably, mice from the BA.M group exhibited a noteworthy rise in the relative abundance of Erysipelotrichaceae and Faecalibacterium within their colon microbiota, while mice from the BA.H group displayed an increase in the relative abundance of Muriaculaceae (P < 0.05).
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between benzoic acid (BA)  and Firmicutes(Bacillota)?

EVIDENCE: exhibits Spearman's correlations between the relative abundance of intestinal microbiota at the genus level and the parameters of inflammation and intestinal function in mice. The cecal levels of butyric acid demonstrated significant correlations with the relative abundances of Staphylococcus, Lactobacillus (showing a negative correlation), Megasphaera, and Prevotella_9 (showing a positive correlation) (P < 0.05). In terms of inflammation, the serum levels of IL-1β showed a strong correlation with the relative abundances of Megasphaera, Prevotella_9 (displaying a negative correlation), and Lactobacillus (displaying a positive correlation) (P < 0.01). Moreover, the serum levels of INF-γ exhibited a positive correlation with the relative abundance of Mucispirillum (P < 0.05). Regarding intestinal integrity, the serum levels of DAO were significantly correlated with the relative abundances of Megasphaera, Prevotella_9, Streptococcu, Bifidobacterium (displaying a negative correlation), and Ligilactobacillus, Staphylococcus (displaying a positive correlation) (P < 0.05). Furthermore, the serum levels of D-lactate displayed a negative correlation with the relative abundance of Colidextribacter (P < 0.05).
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between benzoic acid (BA)  and Staphylococcus?

EVIDENCE: The Pearson correlation analyses of milk miRNAs to healthy infant microbiota were conducted. Significant associations were identified between human milk miRNAs and infant microbial genera and growth irrespective of the mother's dietary protein source (Fig. 5). The resulting clustered image map represents the similarity values extracted from the microbiota data to the miRNA dataset, and the displayed variables were selected based on the first two dimensions, and the dendrograms along the top and left edges of the figure were generated using the complete method. Figure 5A and B depicts a clustered image map of the milk miRNAs correlating with specific infant gut microbiota at 15 and 30 days of age, respectively. In total 35 miRNAs were positively associated with the 8 microbial genera at 15 days of age. At the phylum level, 35 milk miRNAs were associated positively to Firmicutes, Actinobacteria and Proteobacteria early in life. Among the genera, Ruminococcus, Serratia, Micrococcus, Finegoldia, and Peptoniphilus have positively associated with the 28 miRNAs, whereas Blautia, Gemmiger, and Fusicatenibacter positively associated with miR-195-bp, miR335-bp, miR16-5p, miR26b-5p and miR-30c-5p. Interestingly, in 30-day old infants, 10 miRNAs (miR-6802-5p, miR-2467-3p, miR-4441, miR-3937, miR-6778-5p, miR-4451, miR-2392, miR-128-1-5p, miR-4269, miR-1238-5p) were positively correlated with 2 microbial genera Veillonella and Flavonifractor.
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between Human milk miRNAs and genera?

EVIDENCE: However, beta diversity analysis revealed differences in community structure between the PCOS and control groups (P = 0.001) (Fig. 2c). The results of PCoA further confirmed that the samples from the PCOS group were distinctly separate from those of the control (Fig. 2c). LEfSe analysis (Fig. 2d), t test (Fig. S2) and evolutionary tree analysis (Fig. 2e) showed that the abundances of Firmicutes at the phylum level, Clostridia at the class level, Lachnospirales at the order level, and Bacteroidaceae and Lachnospiraceae at the family level in PCOS patients were different from those in the control group. However, at the genus level, only the abundance of Bacteroides in the PCOS group was significantly lower than that in the control group, while the abundance of Agathobacter was higher than that in the control group.

EVIDENCE: The feed Cu content was 9.16 mg/kg. Ternary phase diagram analysis showed the altered abundance of the gut microbes among the groups (Fig. 3a). There was no significant difference in the alpha diversity of the gut microbiota among all groups (P > 0.05, Fig. 3b), but a significant difference in the beta diversity (P < 0.001, Fig. 3c) was found, and PCoA showed that the microbiota profiles of the high-dose Cu group were separated from those of the two other groups (Fig. 3c). LEfSe analysis (Fig. 3d), pairwise comparison between groups (Fig. S5) and phylogenetic evolutionary tree analysis (Fig. 3e) showed that the relative abundances of Roseburia, Helicobacter and Alloprevotella in the low-dose Cu group and Streptomyces and Staphylococcus in the high-dose Cu group were higher than those in the control group. The relative abundance of Akkermansia was lower in the Cu treatment groups than in the control group.
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between High dietarycopper and Roseburia?

EVIDENCE: The 16S rRNA sequencing and LEfSe analysis were performed to assess the effects of NSMJ56 feeding on gut microbiota in laying hens. There were no significant differences in the alpha diversity indices such as ASVs, Chao1, Shannon, and Inverse Simpson (Figure 3A). PCoA analysis indicated that 2 groups were not clearly clustered (Figure 3B). The relative abundance of gut microbiota in laying hens was presented at the phylum, family, and genus levels (Figure 4). At the phylum level, Firmicutes (Control, 70.01 ± 5.68% vs. NSMJ56, 73.90 ± 4.59%), Bacteroidetes (Control, 26.67 ± 5.64% vs. NSMJ56, 22.43 ± 4.90%), and Actinobacteria (Control, 0.54 ± 0.27% vs. NSMJ56, 0.28 ± 0.19%) were the top 3 most abundant phyla (Figure 4A). Lactobacillaceae (Control, 34.69% ± 10.48% vs. NSMJ56, 32.46 ± 6.99%), Bacteroidaceae (Control, 16.13 ± 6.08% vs. NSMJ56, 12.26 ± 5.66%), and Lachnospiraceae (Control, 12.89 ± 3.02% vs. NSMJ56, 14.92 ± 2.60%) were the top 3 most abundant families (Figure 4B), and at the genus level, the top 3 dominant genera were Lactobacillus (Control, 27.30 ± 10.64% vs. NSMJ56, 25.41 ± 6.32%), Mediterranea (Control, 15.01 ± 6.25% vs. NSMJ56, 10.73 ± 6.36%), and Limosilactobacillus (Control, 6.58 ± 4.39% vs. NSMJ56, 6.48 ± 1.73%) (Figure 4C). For differentially abundant taxa at the phylum to genus levels between the control and NSMJ56 groups, LEfSe analysis was found (Figure 5) that Erysipelotrichales, Erysipelotrichia, Flintibater, Dielma, Hespellia, Coprobacter, Roseburia, Anaerotignum, and Coprococcus were enriched in the probiotic group compared with the control group.
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between Lacticaseibacillus paracasei NSMJ56 and Firmicutes(Bacillota)?

At the phylum level, Firmicutes (Control, 70.01 ± 5.68% vs. NSMJ56, 73.90 ± 4.59%), Bacteroidetes (Control, 26.67 ± 5.64% vs. NSMJ56, 22.43 ± 4.90%), and Actinobacteria (Control, 0.54 ± 0.27% vs. NSMJ56, 0.28 ± 0.19%) were the top 3 most abundant phyla (Figure 4A). Lactobacillaceae (Control, 34.69% ± 10.48% vs. NSMJ56, 32.46 ± 6.99%), Bacteroidaceae (Control, 16.13 ± 6.08% vs. NSMJ56, 12.26 ± 5.66%), and Lachnospiraceae (Control, 12.89 ± 3.02% vs. NSMJ56, 14.92 ± 2.60%) were the top 3 most abundant families (Figure 4B), and at the genus level, the top 3 dominant genera were Lactobacillus (Control, 27.30 ± 10.64% vs. NSMJ56, 25.41 ± 6.32%), Mediterranea (Control, 15.01 ± 6.25% vs. NSMJ56, 10.73 ± 6.36%), and Limosilactobacillus (Control, 6.58 ± 4.39% vs. NSMJ56, 6.48 ± 1.73%) (Figure 4C). For differentially abundant taxa at the phylum to genus levels between the control and NSMJ56 groups, LEfSe analysis was found (Figure 5) that Erysipelotrichales, Erysipelotrichia, Flintibater, Dielma, Hespellia, Coprobacter, Roseburia, Anaerotignum, and Coprococcus were enriched in the probiotic group compared with the control group.

EVIDENCE: At the phylum level, as illustrated in Fig. 3, the dominant bacterial sequences belonged predominantly to Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, and Actinobacteria, collectively accounting for over 90 % of the total microbial abundance. The remaining sequences were distributed among lesser-represented phyla such as Patescibacteria, Desulfobacterota, Proteobacteria, Verrucomicrobiota, Deferribacterota, Campilobacterota, and various unclassified bacteria. The dynamic variation in the Firmicutes to Bacteroidetes ratio (F/B value) across different groups is detailed in Table S6. Interestingly, this F/B value trend was consistent in both female and male mice, following the sequence: EKGM groups < medium-dose OKGM groups < control groups. Notably, OKGM administration did not demonstrate a clear dose-dependent effect on the F/B ratio. In comparison, EKGM groups exhibited a lower F/B ratio, potentially due to a decrease in Firmicutes and a concurrent increase in Bacteroidetes with EKGM intake. Prior studies, such as those by Turnbaugh et al. (2006), have indicated that an elevated F/B ratio might enhance the host's fatty acid and energy absorption, potentially leading to weight gain and possibly obesity. Additionally, the relative abundance of Actinobacteria was consistently higher in the high-dose OKGM group compared to the others. The abundance of other bacterial phyla was lower and exhibited random dynamic changes over time.
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between oxidized konjac glucomannan (OKGM) and Firmicutes(Bacillota)?

EVIDENCE: At the phylum level, as illustrated in Fig. 3, the dominant bacterial sequences belonged predominantly to Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, and Actinobacteria, collectively accounting for over 90 % of the total microbial abundance. The remaining sequences were distributed among lesser-represented phyla such as Patescibacteria, Desulfobacterota, Proteobacteria, Verrucomicrobiota, Deferribacterota, Campilobacterota, and various unclassified bacteria. The dynamic variation in the Firmicutes to Bacteroidetes ratio (F/B value) across different groups is detailed in Table S6. Interestingly, this F/B value trend was consistent in both female and male mice, following the sequence: EKGM groups < medium-dose OKGM groups < control groups. Notably, OKGM administration did not demonstrate a clear dose-dependent effect on the F/B ratio. In comparison, EKGM groups exhibited a lower F/B ratio, potentially due to a decrease in Firmicutes and a concurrent increase in Bacteroidetes with EKGM intake. Prior studies, such as those by Turnbaugh et al. (2006), have indicated that an elevated F/B ratio might enhance the host's fatty acid and energy absorption, potentially leading to weight gain and possibly obesity. Additionally, the relative abundance of Actinobacteria was consistently higher in the high-dose OKGM group compared to the others. The abundance of other bacterial phyla was lower and exhibited random dynamic changes over time.
QUESTIONS: What is the relationship between oxidized konjac glucomannan (OKGM) and Bacteroidetes(Bacteroidia)?

We observed dynamic shifts in the species showing significant variations between the groups of female and male mice over the 30, 60, and 90-day intervals. Notably, Lactobacillus_murinus emerged as the predominant species showing marked differences among the female groups at 30 days, with its highest abundance recorded in the EKF group, surpassing levels in both the CF and MOKF groups. EVIDENCE: The 90-day analysis revealed Enterococcus faecium, Lactobacillus acidophilus, and Pediococcus pentosaceus as the predominant species, with Enterococcus faecium displaying a significantly higher level in the CM group compared to MOKM and EKM groups. Enterococcus faecium, recognized as a crucial nosocomial pathogen, poses heightened infection risks, especially in immunocompromised patients (Arias et al., 2012; Van Tyne & Gilmore, 2014). In contrast, Lactobacillus reuteri, a beneficial gram-positive bacterium, is known for its numerous health benefits, including digestive aid, immune enhancement, and infection prevention (Mu, Tavella, & Luo, 2018). Intriguingly, the control group exhibited a higher relative abundance of Enterococcus faecium compared to both OKGM and EKGM groups, whereas Lactobacillus reuteri thrived more in the OKGM and EKGM groups than in the control group. This pattern suggests a potential antagonistic relationship between Lactobacillus reuteri and Enterococcus faecium in the gut, supported by findings that Lactobacillus reuteri secretes Reuterin, a broad-spectrum antimicrobial substance, curbing the growth of pathogenic bacteria (Mu et al., 2018). The analysis of intergroup differences further
